Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IPY: GAMBIT: Gamburtsev Aerogeophysical Mapping of Bedrock and Ice Targets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports an aerogeophysical study of the Gamburtsev Subglacial Mountains (GSM), a Texas-sized mountain range buried beneath the ice sheets of East Antarctica. The project would perform a combined gravity, magnetics, and radar study to achieve a range of goals including: advancing our understanding of the origin and evolution of the polar ice sheets and subglacial lakes; defining the crustal architecture of East Antarctica, a key question in the earth's history; and locating the oldest ice in East Antarctica, which may ultimately help find ancient climate records. Virtually unexplored, the GSM represents the largest unstudied area of crustal uplift on earth. As well, the region is the starting point for growth of the Antarctic ice sheets.
Because of these outstanding questions, the GSM has been identified by the international Antarctic science community as a research focus for the International Polar Year (2007-2009). In addition to this study, NSF is also supporting a seismological survey of the GSM under award number 0537371. Major international partners in the project include Germany, China, Australia, and the United Kingdom. For more information see IPY Project #67 at IPY.org. In terms of broader impacts, this project also supports postdoctoral and graduate student research, and various forms of outreach including a focus on groups underrepresented in the earth sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, “Collaborative Research: IPY: GAMBIT: Gamburtsev Aerogeophysical Mapping of Bedrock and Ice Targets” or AGAP, was in collaboration with PI Robin Bell and her team at LDEO, and Michael Studinger at NASA/GSFC, as well as investigators from the USGS, University of Kansas/CRESIS, BGR, BAS, and others. The overall goals of the project were to field an aerogeophysical campaign to map the last unexplored mountain range, the Gamburtsev mountains under the East Antarctic Plateau. Data gathered by aircraft flown by US and British Antarctic Survey aircraft succeeded in mapping the area with ice penetrating radar, surface elevations from a laser altimeter, and gravimetry.  The results revealed both the character of the mountain range, which shows evidence for a pre-ice-cover network of valleys, and also more about the tectonic setting of the area, which helps geologists understand the history of mountain formation here. One fundamental result from the team was the identification of large areas of basal freeze on of ice to the ice sheet; this is a phenomenon that had not been documented at this scale before. The University of New Hampshire/University of Alaska (PI Fahnestock before and after transfering to UAF) part of this effort had specific goals in supporting roles to the AGAP teams main efforts: 1) Participation in the design of the observation program to ensure that glaciologically relevant data were gathered. To this end UNH/UAF put together, with Michael Studinger, at that time at Lamont, a planning tool that displayed what was known about the area, and what the planned US and BAS flight lines were to be, in a flexible way. This tool played an integral role in the planning process, and has since been used for some of the data visualization and interpretation efforts of the group. Layers put togehter for the tool are still live in support of flight planning for NASA’s Operation IceBridge Antarctic Campaigns. 2) Work on the ice penetrating radar records that would be gathered, to extract information about the ice sheet and its history and flow. This work had an emphasis on techniques for quantitatively capturing internal layering in ice-penetrating radar data and understanding the character of the scatterers within the ice.
